segments.text: If it's five minutes or ten minutes, it doesn't matter.
Okay, I think now we're up to question four.
Question four.
What do you feel is the best solution to the war?
Or to peace.
No, I think you've put it precisely, and I like that.
The best solution to the war...

it involves the four parties to the war and four armies involved in the war now agreeing for the normal political reasons on a ceasefire and some form of power sharing wars always end in one of two ways either one side

wins and defeats the other and that ends the war or you have some form of stalemate and the war reaches the point where all sides or most of the parties to realize there must be some form of negotiated settlement and compromise

and I think without a doubt the war in Cambodia is one of those wars that nobody's ever going to win militarily in any decisive way and it's also a war which can go on at its present level low intensity level that heavily ideologically laden expression it could go on for a long time
And it's not a question of the war being fueled by external supplies of arms entirely.
The war will go on for a long time because there's some serious political disputes amongst these parties.
And they will find weapons locally if, in fact, supplies are cut off from one external source, no doubt about it.
Okay, so there has to be some form of negotiated solution to the war.
At present, this has proved impossible.
Because, in spite of what they say, the Phnom Penh people, the Ho Ninh Tsen government and the Hang Sơn Minh party, backed by Vietnam, really don't want negotiations.
They still want a solution which leaves the legitimate People's Party and the biggest revolutionary government in power

And what they are trying to do is to bring international opinion, public opinion, the media, aid agencies, and Western liberal governments around to their point of view by campaigning against the Khmer Rouge.

by discrediting the other side by laying claims which are cogent and credible within the framework of our liberal tradition which will allow them to have the government which they see to be necessary within their strategic
framework and also just within their communist revolutionary proletarian international way of looking at things so they're playing tough they're playing a very hard game
They're asking for everything.

They're trying to win the war politically by means of this worldwide mobilization of public opinion, trying to win the war with propaganda that they have, in some sense, failed to win with the invasion force and the occupation force.
So the idea is to isolate the Khmer Rouge, to isolate Siena, to isolate the KPMG, the middle class nationalists by political means rather than military means.
That's their strategy.
And the Paris conference failed last August.
or I should say it didn't progress very far because the Vietnamese and the Phnom Penh people were not prepared to negotiate very much at all.
Of course they said they're prepared to talk about this and that, they're prepared to have international observer forces look at this and look at that, and verify this and verify that.
But they always wanted these mechanisms set up, or these observer forces reporting to themselves, not to the UN, and thereby recognizing what they call the de facto political reality.

so they're using the iron fist if you like to continue to demand everything and in a subtle way also to blackmail us in the West by using the very serious plight of the people the horrific social conditions the appalling shocking economic
realities in the country to encourage us to say,

as is said by the Oxfam people who are in John Pilger's film to kind of give up on the political front and say oh all right you know we'll just feed the people we'll just recognize you give you development you know pretend it didn't happen pretend there never was any patience it is blackmail let me let me stress that the

they criticize the Thai government and the United Nations for using refugee camps to carry on with the war and they say the refugees in those camps are political pawns well, they do the same thing they're using the people inside the country and the needs of those people inside the country as political pawns and shoving these pawns on our TV screens all the time and trying to persuade us to come around to their political position

So the best solution clearly is some form of compromise, some form of power sharing, some form of internationally controlled ceasefire and armistice followed by the demobilization of substantial numbers of troops from all four armies
I mean all four not simply the Khmer Rouge people talk about the Khmer Rouge all the time but there are four armies here and the second largest

force to be demobilized the central army the Phnom Penh regime and it's very important that they be disarmed and demobilized because the Soviets have given them extraordinary quantities of arms and from what I can see from what my friends in Phnom Penh tell me that army is not a very disciplined army

and when they go into battle they take these soviet weapons and they're huge stocks of bullets and artillery shells and they just you know blanket artillery carpet carpet artillery shelling which is very destructive
any international force that goes into Cambodia has to grab those arms depots and arms caches everywhere a lot of weaponry in this country now that armistice

and internationally supervised ceasefire and relocation of the troops must take place alongside political arrangements for the reorganization of the government of Phnom Penh and the central administration of Phnom Penh.
political arrangements for elections and this will likely involve so many sort of census of a population and the establishment of an electoral register, we would call it in Britain.
People have to register to vote and there have to be ways to be found to ensure that everybody who is eligible is in fact allowed to vote and that there's no cheating, that some villages don't.

have electoral registers which gave each citizen 10 votes like the payrolls of the Mondo army exactly and and if this isn't carefully controlled everyone will be doing that everyone will have stress and everyone will say the Khmer Rouge are cheating but every Cambodian will cheat a lot of a lot of the nasty things that are said about the Khmer Rouge are really
indicative of common practices amongst Cambodians.
But there's never been very clean elections in Cambodia.
It's the same in most very well-known countries.
So arranging an election will be time consuming.
It will probably take governments a year to arrange the election.
But it shouldn't take more than two years.
And that's important.
Things should move right along once there is a basic agreement on an interim political authority, international control and supervision, a ceasefire,
demobilization, reorganization of administration, basically to incorporate people from the other three parties and also to begin the process of receiving close to 700,000 Cambodians who are overseas.
Let me stress that number.
Regime Phnom Penh keeps saying,
They have to keep their full administration because there are no more skilled people left to govern the country, and they retrain a lot of people.

well it is true that a certain number of educated people were killed under Pol Pot but basically again this argument is propaganda and a pretext too for continuing to lock out if you like all of that talent which is in the US and France and Belgium especially in France of course
with a couple hundred thousand Cambodians anxious to go back home.
And they were the best educated people to begin with, and now their children have grown up and have been well educated.
So there are a lot of skilled Cambodians in the world who could contribute to the

to the peace process and to the reconstruction of their country and these people simply must be allowed to come back and they cannot come back unless there's a negotiation politically they're denounced as dangerous elements

and all sorts of excuses are used to keep them out unless of course now they want to do business with Phnom Penh because going through one of those periods of liberal reform in Phnom Penh which is designed to make the party more popular than it really is or make it appear to be more popular than it
than it has been.

So this problem of the repatriation of refugees in the border camps and the repatriation of people who settled abroad is crucial to a successful settlement, to a settlement that will last, to a settlement that will lead to

post-war reconstruction trying to repair the roads rapidly and get things back in order as well as post-war development there has to be two steps here and the country needs every engineer every accountant every planner every land development expert every urban development expert that's ever trained in that field to make

and make the best use of the international aid and reconstruction and development money which will be forthcoming if there is a settlement within the framework of the Paris Conference so in a couple of sentences the best solution to the war is a solution which is worked out within the framework of the Paris Conference which involves in the normal way UN control and supervision
And the worst solution is the solution that the Vietnamese and Hong San people kept trying to promote at Paris.

August and keep trying to sell if you like to their solution which they call a partial solution or sometimes they call it an external solution involves simply a symbolic coalition between the Phnom Penh
the Cambodian People's Revolutionary Party and CNU, or maybe CNU and the KPMG, excluding the Khmer Rouge.
This solution is no solution at all.

they say it will isolate the Khmer Rouge and the Khmer Rouge will be finished but that's untrue that's untrue because the Khmer Rouge represent a certain nationalist force and the Khmer Rouge have a certain level of support which incidentally will remain loyal as long as the Vietnamese are seen to be controlling things in Phnom Penh because that is the essence of it

Khmer Rouge nationalism they are opposed to Vietnamese colonialism in Cambodia Khmer Rouge nationalism defends Khmer independence, Cambodian independence and they can always rally people on that basis

privately at Paris and earlier in Jakarta Hun Sen kept assuring Siena well if you come over to us if you join us there will be just a little war and we could live with it we keep them out of pain and things will be all right
But this is utopian.
This is a trick.
I don't think Hun Sen got stupid.
But in Hun Sen's point of view, his current position now is preferable to what his position would be in a real coalition.

he prefers a symbolic coalition with Siena because that would strengthen his position from what it is now but it certainly wouldn't end the war it wouldn't bring peace now let me end by saying the way you formulated the question
The beginning is more precise.
The best solution, or the best course towards peace, in my view, begins with ending the war.
Now, the human rights activists in Oxfam and some of the American groups, David Hawkes can go to the Documentation Commission for America,

they would say the way to peace is to deal with the Khmer Rouge to maybe punish them, put them on trial, eliminate them, discredit them, you know outlaw them, Aksan people now talking about outlawing the Khmer Rouge quite how one does it, I don't know, but anyway that's what they say and in their view this is the way to peace but it's a sort of moral, elusive, imagined peace

The best solution is, first of all, to find ways to end the war and then you engage in political compromise as you take into account who has power, who has administrative power, who has royal power, who has military power and you put together a coalition which will allow the country to have a government which is different from the one that we've had before which is not dominated by the Canary, not dominated by the Siam, not dominated by the Huns and the people

and which is internationally supervised and where people have in some sense to use an American expression their heads knocked together by international bodies now and again because there will be conflict, there will be assassinations, there will be trouble but it will be much less trouble and much less dangerous for most people than the situation that exists now which is very dangerous
